articles.summary:

available online by subscription only. Articles include: "Looking upstream for
influences on socioeconomic inequalities in health" by Ted Schrecker and
Eugene Milne "The vulnerability of being ill informed: … Read More

new cases that is currently in place continues, and no new cases are detected,

articles.summary:
A new study suggests that Earth’s magnetic field could take just 100 years to
flip - and there’s evidence it could happen again in a couple of thousand
years.
articles.title: Earth’s magnetic field could flip much faster than previously predicted (Science Alert)

articles.author: By ALISON SMALE
articles.summary:
The man, 56, who had been working with the United Nations in Liberia, was the
third patient to arrive in Germany in recent weeks for treatment, and the
first to die.
articles.title: Ebola Patient Dies in German Hospital (NY Times)

articles.summary:
Clinical trials rarely include children; as a result, less than half of all
drugs are approved for pediatric use. What can be done?

articles.title: Meager Dosage Data for Kids Makes for Uncertain Prescriptions (Scientific American)

articles.author: Elizabeth Howell
articles.summary:
A NASA spacecraft has been out of radio contact for about two weeks, but the
agency is still holding out hopes for a rescue. One of the STEREO (Solar
TErrestrial RElations Observatory) spacecraft stopped phoning home to Earth on
Oct. 1 "immediately after a planned reset of the spacecraft", NASA said in an
update last […]
articles.title: NASA Solar Forecasting Takes A Hit As Sun-Gazing Spacecraft Stops Phoning Home (Universe Today)

dramatically

articles.title: Oxygen-Free Recycling Technique Could Keep Tons Of Plastics From Landfills (Scientific American)

articles.author: MSNBC: Jane C. Timm
articles.summary:
MSNBC: A full 97% of researchers taking a stance on climate change say it`s
man-made, as do 97-98% of the most frequently-published climate scientists.
But according to Wisconsin Rep. Paul Ryan, they`re all wrong. When asked
during an election debate Monday if he believed humans cause climate change,
the former Republican vice presidential nominee joined the growing number of
Republicans who refuse to acknowledge the overwhelming scientific consensus
that humans are influencing the Earth`s climate. “I...
articles.title: Paul Ryan: Science doesn't get climate change (climateark)

articles.summary:
Like discriminating thieves, prostate cancer tumors scavenge and hoard copper
that is an essential element in the body. But such avarice may be a fatal
weakness.
articles.title: Prostate cancer's penchant for copper may be a fatal flaw (Eurekalert)

articles.author: AFP
articles.summary:
The news excites researchers, who know little about an animal that spends much
of its time diving at depth far from shore.
articles.title: Rare Beaked Whale Washes Up in Australia (Discovery)

articles.author: By NIDA NAJAR
articles.summary:
Looming state elections have whipped up the fight by Hindu activists to
protect cows and the rumors about their mistreatment at the hands of Muslims.
articles.title: Rumors of Cow Killings in India Deepen Rift Between Hindus and Muslims (New York Times)

articles.summary:
The wonder of bird migration takes a long while to sink in. Perhaps it’s the
payload, but tiny birds still seem able to amaze us with their ability to fly
thousands of kilometres (or even miles.) This is a unique Australian endemic
bird that seems able to detect water a great distances, possibly by smell of
desert, air, their brine shrimp food or other olfaction.
articles.title: Stilt break records for migration and finding water. (Earth Times)

articles.summary:
First research of its kind shows that tasers could impair a person's memory
and thought process
articles.title: Taser's 50,000-volt jolt can mess up your brain (CBS News)
